title: Quantum Random Access Codes for Boolean Functions
abstract:
Abstract
An n​↦𝑝​m𝑛𝑝maps-to𝑚n\overset{p}{\mapsto}m random access code (RAC) is an encoding of n𝑛n bits into m𝑚m bits such that any initial bit can be recovered with probability at least p𝑝p, while in a quantum RAC (QRAC), the n𝑛n bits are encoded into m𝑚m qubits. Since its proposal, the idea of RACs was generalized in many different ways, e.g. allowing the use of shared entanglement (called entanglement-assisted random access code, or simply EARAC) or recovering multiple bits instead of one. In this paper we generalize the idea of RACs to recovering the value of a given Boolean function f𝑓f on any subset of fixed size of the initial bits, which we call f𝑓f-random access codes. We study and give protocols for f𝑓f-random access codes with classical (f𝑓f-RAC) and quantum (f𝑓f-QRAC) encoding, together with many different resources, e.g. private or shared randomness, shared entanglement (f𝑓f-EARAC) and Popescu-Rohrlich boxes (f𝑓f-PRRAC). The success probability of our protocols is characterized by the noise stability of the Boolean function f𝑓f. Moreover, we give an upper bound on the success probability of any f𝑓f-QRAC with shared randomness that matches its success probability up to a multiplicative constant (and f𝑓f-RACs by extension), meaning that quantum protocols can only achieve a limited advantage over their classical counterparts.
